urn:contentItem:5VVT-D411-JCCP-051J-00000-00Westerman Statement on Net Neutrality Vote;Rep. Bruce Westerman (R-AR) News Release2019-04-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexisU.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES DOCUMENTSWesterman Statement on Net Neutrality VoteRep. Bruce Westerman (R-AR) News Release

WASHINGTON - Today, U.S. Rep. Bruce Westerman (R-Ark.) issued the following statement on the House's vote on the Save the Internet Act:

"The internet isn't broken, so why are liberals trying to fix it? In this legislation, House Democrats want to give federal entities nearly unlimited authority to regulate the internet, which is why I voted against it. I support the bipartisan and commonsense 'bright line' rules for net neutrality - no blocking, no throttling and no paid prioritization - that protect consumers, but the Save the Internet Act reaches far beyond these commonsense protections. In rural districts like mine, this bill would slow down or reduce network expansion, a critical delay as I fight to expand broadband connectivity in remote areas.

"This isn't even the first time we've had a net neutrality debate. When President Trump first announced he was repealing regulations, liberals would not stop talking about how this would radically change the internet as we knew it. But when the regulations ceased, these doomsday predictions fell flat. Life continued uninterrupted, and Americans enjoyed affordable and reliable internet access.

"This so-called attempt to 'save the internet' has nothing to do with better internet service; it's a gift to edge providers who want to market personal data. GOP members have introduced at least three bills that would protect consumers without overbearing government involvement - let's focus our attention on those practical solutions instead."

Background:

The Save the Internet Act would:

* Allow the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to set prices, sanction investments and dictate how broadband companies interact with their customers.

* Lay the groundwork for taxing and overregulating the internet.

* Require FCC approval for development of new 5G and other innovative technologies, which would discourage, delay or block them altogether.

* Limit access for rural Americans. Studies show that 80 percent of providers in rural areas incurred additional expenses when complying with the Obama-era net neutrality regulations, which led to delayed or reduced network expansion.

* Allow big tech corporations like Facebook and Google to undermine American families' privacy.

Read this original document at: https://westerman.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/westerman-statement-net-neutrality-vote

urn:contentItem:5VWN-V4S1-JC8V-13TG-00000-00Western governments enter uncharted territory as they grapple with problem of harmful content on social media2019-04-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexisTECWestern governments enter uncharted territory as they grapple with problem of harmful content on social media Zen Soo

In 2018 UN investigators concluded that the Myanmar military had for years used social media platform Facebook as a tool to enable ethnic cleansing of the Muslim Rohingyas. Hundreds of Facebook pages had been set up, populated with content aimed at inciting hatred against the Rohingyas and forcing hundreds of thousands to flee the genocide taking place.

However, the tipping point on what seems to be acceptable internet discourse and content appeared to come last month, when an Australian gunman live-streamed a mass shooting at two Christchurch mosques. Three weeks later, sweeping legislation conceived and passed in five days was enacted in Australia to punish social media companies that fail to remove "abhorrent, violent material" on their platforms "expeditiously".

Under Australia's new legislation, employees of social media sites face up to three years in prison and the companies involved could be fined up to 10 per cent of their annual profit.

Australia is not alone. Governments around the world, including the UK and Singapore, have moved to take a more active role in deciding what constitutes acceptable content in an era where social media content is king and anything can be shared at the push of a button.

"It's dystopian, but I think China's [regulation method] is going to be the future," said Aram Sinnreich, an associate professor at American University's School of Communication, referring to the "Great Firewall" that blocks foreign social media platforms and censors content deemed politically sensitive or disruptive to public order.

For the West and many other countries, government regulation of social media is uncharted territory. Proposals to regulate for the sake of public interest have been met with fears that it would impede freedom of expression, even as platforms like Facebook - which eventually removed the anti-Rohingya sites - agree that internet companies should be "accountable for enforcing standards on harmful content".

Should New Zealand ban manifesto of accused Christchurch killer?

Experts say that the core of the issue is that while internet companies like Facebook and some governments want to do the right thing in the name of public interest, nobody has come up with a solution that would do so without potentially affecting rights like free speech.

The dangers of allowing a platform to self-regulate were highlighted when a Bloomberg report recently found that video-streaming platform YouTube's top executives, focused on increasing the amount of time users spent watching its videos, allowed its algorithm to recommend videos bordering on hate speech or pushing conspiracy theories as these videos tended to attract large numbers of views.

"At the beginning, governments intended for platforms to self-regulate, but obviously this has not worked," said Fu King-wa, an associate professor at the University of Hong Kong's Journalism and Media Studies Centre.

"Now governments around the world are taking it seriously to [protect] social media in their local communities, not just from inappropriate content, but also from disinformation especially when it comes from another country."

Singapore, always circumspect about how media can be used to inflame religious and racial fault lines, earlier this month unveiled a draft law aimed at punishing individuals and social media sites from maliciously spreading online falsehoods.

Individuals in Singapore who fabricate news or refuse to comply when asked to remove falsehoods could face a decade in prison or fines of up S$20,000 (US$14,765). Firms can be fined up to S$1 million.

Why Southeast Asia internet laws are starting to look like China's

The UK last week released the Online Harms White Paper which proposed broad social media regulations, including instituting a new regulator with enforcement powers to fine companies and executives who breach the "code of practice" by failing to remove content promoting terrorism, hate crimes and self-harm.

The origins of the fight against inappropriate content and disinformation can be traced back to 2016, amid discoveries of Russian interference and hoards of fake news sites originating in Macedonia, aimed at influencing the US elections and Brexit. That was when the potential for social media platforms to be used maliciously to influence society came to the forefront of social consciousness.

Social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter are inherently vulnerable to disinformation because they allow individuals to target advertisements and content at specific groups of people based on characteristics like age, gender, education-level and even political and religious beliefs.

"The kind of disinformation campaigns we've seen are endemic to the platform and cannot be stopped without changing the entire platform and business models," said Sinnreich.

He pointed out that the worst case scenario for democratic countries would be if governments implement social media regulations, thereby creating the apparatus for a totalitarian state to exist, allowing political leaders to control access to the internet.

No bikinis in the bedroom: China's war to 'clean up' the internet

The complex nature of how social media platforms are structured have led some to believe that these companies are now too big to fail. US presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has called for the government to break up big tech companies like Amazon, Google and Facebook. Her argument is that they wield too much power by monopolising the market and using private information for profit, which in turn allows foreign actors to exert social control.

Facebook and other platforms have moved to tighten advertising rules to prevent such misuse. In March Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg called for governments to play a more active role in regulating the internet. "Lawmakers often tell me we have too much power over speech, and frankly I agree," said Zuckerberg in a statement. "I've come to believe that we shouldn't make so many important decisions about speech on our own."

The Facebook founder proposed a standardised approach when it comes to deciding what counts as harmful content and to regulate political advertisements online.

The question of whether social media can and should be regulated has sparked debate around the world, primarily because such regulations are uncharted territory. Traditionally, in many countries, free speech, the press and advertising are considered separate and may have different regulations. But social media platforms today are a combination of everything - from interpersonal communication, content publishing and even advertising.

"Platforms are kind of like vertically-integrated chimera, like a beast made up of many different other beasts," said Sinnreich.

Imposing a regulation on a platform might be applicable for one type of content, such as advertising, but the same regulation may be inappropriate for other functions such as private messages between users, he pointed out.

"Platforms are so opaque that it's impossible for regulators to figure out where one begins and the other ends ... it's hard to regulate uniformly, but it's also hard to regulate piecemeal," he said.

The global trend towards regulating online content has provoked fears of censorship and restrictions on free speech and civil liberties. In the case of broadly-defined regulation, this might inadvertently cause platforms to err on the side of caution and go overboard in censoring themselves.

"When lawmakers create new rules that have never been tested by courts - like Australia's new law or the rules proposed in the UK's White Paper - and then tell platforms to enforce them, we can only expect that a broad swathe of perfectly legal speech is going to disappear," said Daphne Keller, director of intermediary liability at the Stanford Centre for Internet and Society.

"Even lawmakers telling platforms to enforce existing laws should expect bad results when they impose such heavy penalties on platforms. The incentive is to silence anything that falls in a grey area, or anything that an accuser claims is illegal."

Chinese Game of Throne fans resigned to final season censorship

In some cases, critics say such laws and legislation place too much power in the hands of governments to decide what kind of content is acceptable.

Singapore's draft law, for example, has been criticised because it relies on the Singapore government deciding whether the news in question is factual, and gives it the power to issue mandatory corrections.

The government has said the law is targeted only at those who deliberately fabricate news and those who spread it without knowing the truth "don't have to be concerned".

The Southeast Asian island state already ranks poorly in terms of press freedom, at No. 151 out of 180 countries and regions, compared to China's ranking of 176th.

Ultimately, comprehensive social media regulations should be accompanied by a mechanism where platforms and individuals have the opportunity to challenge removals and penalties can be imposed on those who abuse the system.

"Every country faces the problem of regulating and protecting speech. Ultimately, it's a constitutional and political issue," said Lei Ya-wen, assistant professor of sociology at Harvard University.

"One major difference between how China deals with the problem and how many other countries deal with it is whether citizens have functioning legal channels to dispute the government's administrative decisions, judicial decisions, regulations, and laws."

Boris could win votes by investing in Wales

It's tempting to see the dramatic departure of Chancellor Sajid Javid as the work of the Prime Minister's special advisor, and pantomime villain, Dominic Cummings.

But it's really about interventionist policies, which we have needed for decades.

Javid is a Thatcherite, Boris is a big spender on infrastructure. His faults are too numerous to mention, but he's right on that.

The Prime Minister knows that in order to be returned to power he must deliver for the North, and North Midlands, and keep his new MPs there. There aren't many Tory MPs in South Wales, but they should still be lobbying for some kind of, perhaps slimmed-down, Swansea Barrage.

There is still a chance, but they must attract the PM's attention and persuade him there are more seats to win in Wales at the next election, if he invests. At the moment he is just looking northwards.

John Gemmell

Wem, Shropshire

Critics of 24-hour lights proved right

Just a while ago there was correspondence about the amount of electricity apparently being wasted by keeping all the lights switched on for 24 hours a day.

We were told that this was for security reasons and a HMRC spokesperson was adamant as to the necessity for this practice, advising us that there was no alternative.

Well, so much for such a statement, it hasn't gone unnoticed that there was in fact an alternative after all.

The lighting has since been reduced to a fraction of the intensity that it once was.

Top marks for those who highlighted the problem and bottom marks for the HMRC official who tried to defend it.

Brian Francis

Grangetown, Cardiff

HS2 could fall foul of our pothole problem

The Prime Minister has just given the go-ahead for the HS2 project.

HS2 has to be a part of a national integrated transport network and unless the whole network is functioning efficiently, the knock-on effect would seriously challenge the justification for building HS2.

The brochure for the proposed HS2 train is claiming a journey time saving of about 30 minutes between London and Birmingham.

That saving is on the HS2 train's journey between the station in London and the station in Birmingham, but that doesn't account for the journey that a passengers will be making.

The train journey is only a part of a passenger's journey, which may begin from a location that is miles from the departure station and end in a location which is miles from the arrival station.

These journeys to and from the stations are the cause of my concern, which is that the usual ongoing delays, traffic jams and roadworks on existing roads that frequently disrupt road travel plans will still be there, and will virtually cancel out the time saved on the train journey. Has anyone seen a strategic plan for the urgent work needed to rectify the appalling state of our pothole-ridden roads

If a passenger's journey start is close to the departure station and journey's end is close to the arrivals station, then that 30 minutes may be reasonably claimed as significant. But the vast majority will not be close for one reason or the other, and on that basis alone, the cost justification for HS2 appears flawed.

It would be a good idea if the Prime Minister could fend off his critics by ordering and funding a plan to repair properly the roads in Wales.

Kevin Granville

Peterson-super-Ely

We ignore biblical teaching at our peril

The stark juxtaposition of two letters in Tuesday's Western Mail highlighted a serious problem in today's society.

Mr Mike Beech and his friend experienced extreme embarrassment as they endured obscene behaviour and foul language on a ferry to Ireland.

The letter from Steve Denton commented on the apparent delight of Ms Jane Bryant, Assembly Member for Newport West, and Pride Cymru at the success achieved by LGBTQ+ in the cancellation of a UK evangelical tour by Franklin Graham, the son of Dr Billy Graham, on the grounds that his views about sexual, gender and extreme religious issues mirrored the principles expressed in the book of all books, the Bible.

Those principles are the antithesis of the behaviour and language Mr Beech experienced but which are commonplace in many Welsh towns and cities.

Among other things, the Bible teaches standards of decency, human dignity, respect for all others, sexual morality, national equality, tolerance, love, forgiveness, parental guidance and discipline, self-control, etc, etc. Tragically, it seems that our society has little or no interest in fostering those principles but insists upon bombarding us even in our homes with drama, reality shows and so-called entertainment that frequently exemplify the degrading behaviour and speech Mr Beech refers to.

What we are seeing in our land today is the direct result of recent generations' refusal to accept or even hear the Bible's blueprint for human beliefs and practice, let alone teach those values to our children. The wholesale collapse of moral standards in the UK is at risk until or unless the right to address the issue is given, and responded to freely and positively.

When will it dawn upon us as parents, grandparents, teachers, political leaders and all who exercise influence on our young people that we are responsible right now and will remain guilty until such time as we return to the God upon Whom we all depend for life itself, and listen to what He has to say about the state of our nation

Mr Graham has spent the past 40-plus years working his socks off to bring physical relief to people suffering from extreme famine, war, disease and poverty in over 100 countries, as CEO and chairman of a relief organisation, Samaritan's Purse.

Geoffrey Dodge

Usk

Tech firms have duty to safeguard children

I'm hugely encouraged by the landmark plans afoot to give Ofcom powers to regulate social networks. The safety of children online has been compromised for too long, but this breakthrough could pave the way in setting a global standard in protecting children in their digital worlds.

The plans announced by the UK Government highlight a commitment to leading change by standing up to big tech firms.

Now, Ofcom must be given the necessary powers, allowing it to enforce substantial fines on social networks not doing enough to prevent adults grooming children on their sites.

The internet is a wonderful place for young people to learn and social networks form a big part of their friendships, enabling them to seek support from peers. However, no longer should children be exposed to harmful content and abuse because of a slapdash approach by tech giants.

In just two years 2017-18 to 2018-19 there were 7,500 online grooming crimes recorded by police in England and Wales.

It's gone on too long and social networks must not be allowed to continue dragging their heels. It's why NSPCC Cymru/Wales has long called for, through our Wild West Web campaign, an independent regulator, safe accounts for children and detailed reporting on how tech firms are keeping children safe.

Emma Motherwell

Local Campaigns Manager, NSPCC Cymru

PM's flunkies shield him from criticism

Just imagine if Boris Johnson was an opposition politician.

Right-wing commentators would be raging about his sexual proclivities, about his use of drugs and his cowardly deviousness at suppressing information and avoiding any scrutiny.

They would fume at his betrayal of Brexit by compromising Northern Ireland's position and how he betrayed the United States over the Huawei deal.

And of course they would condemn him for nationalising railways and for giving the go-ahead for a scheme that wasted billions and destroyed ancient woodlands...but he is a Tory Brexiteer, so it makes all those things 'ok'.

Nigel Baker

Roath, Cardiff

Wales stuck in a rut thanks to Labour

For years Labour AMs, MPs and councillors have continued to pull the wool over voters' eyes, while running with the fox and hounds.

They freely campaign against Labour policies - what a blatant example of double standards.

Come the next election, these same politicians will blame everyone else and not their own policies.

Labour has dug Wales into a social rut and they haven't got the tools to get the country out.

Andrew Nutt

Bargoed

urn:contentItem:5VF1-CGC1-JB20-G2SB-00000-00Western Union Co at Goldman Sachs Technology & Internet Conference - Final2019-02-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexis021219a12304636.736Western Union Coat Goldman SachsTechnology & Internet Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Hikmet Ersek

The Western Union Company- President, CEO & Director

* Rajesh K. Agrawal

The Western Union Company- Executive VP & CFO

Conference Call Participants

* James Edward Schneider

Goldman Sachs GroupInc., Research Division - VP

Presentation

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER, VP, GOLDMAN SACHS GROUPINC., RESEARCH DIVISION: All right. Good afternoon, everybody. Welcome to Western Unionpresentation at the Goldman SachsTechnology Internet Conference. My name is Jim Schneider. I'm the payments analyst here at Goldman in research. And it's my pleasure to introduce Western Uniontoday. We're really, really happy to have CEO, Hikmet Ersek; and CFO, Raj Agrawal, with us today from the company. Welcome, guys.

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL, EXECUTIVE VP & CFO, THE WESTERN UNION COMPANY: Thank you.

HIKMET ERSEK, PRESIDENT, CEO & DIRECTOR, THE WESTERN UNION COMPANY: Hi.

Questions and Answers

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Macro. I think, Hikmet, one thing that we're trying to do with all of our companies at the conference. And I think the top thing on all investors' minds right now is the macro environment and what you're seeing. You operate in over 200 countries, so you probably have the best handle on the pulse of this than almost anybody else here. So can you give us an idea of the trends, what you're seeing in the major markets and corridors right now at a broad level?

HIKMET ERSEK: It's not a big change since 2018, but maybe a little bit more cautious than 2018. Especially coming the last quarter in 2018, we could see some of the -- a little bit slower, growing slower. However, generally, I would say that in our guidance, everything is planned in our guidance. U.S. has a good economic environment. Europe is stable. Parts of Europe, Southern Europe has some challenges, but Europe generally, U.K., France and Germany, they are key countries for us and doing pretty well. As you know, Asia is doing well, but it's not an outbound country for us. The oil prices in the Middle East helped our business to stabilize. We implemented some pricing actions last year there, which is going to be on -- it's going to be 12 months now in the second quarter. We see some turnaround there. Also, the transactions are coming better, and people are using remittance market, sending back money home. I would say the biggest question is the currency volatility. It is volatile. Strong euro doesn't help our -- in our business in the reported base because, as you know, most of our transactions are -- adopted dollars on. And so that is -- has an impact to our reported numbers. However, constant currency, I would say, general the business is stable, resilient and customers are using us.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. And then there has been some discussion by some of your competitors or peers, I would say, more in the payments world that kind of -- that are tied more to retail commerce that the travel-related trends, especially whether that's being the strength of the dollar or whatever it is, those are getting impacted. I'm just kind of curious, I mean, most of your trends are clearly tied to migration and labor, but I'm curious whether you're seeing any kind of knock-on impacts of the cross-border travel and the -- for example, people coming to U.S. on business.

HIKMET ERSEK: Well, on the -- as you said, our customers are mainly migrant background, and they do use our service, they continue to use our services. Even the -- during the high volatility of currencies, customers use us, right. I mean, they send back money home what they earned, and that helps us. The transaction strength has been quite strong. And even the principal amount, we were growing by 7% constant currency last quarter, which shows that we're a stable business. And so the customers are continuing to use us, and we don't see big impact. The very strong growth is coming from new customer segment from westernunion.com, our digital channel. It grew by 25% last quarter in transaction terms and over 22% revenue terms. So it's a quite strong. We are gaining new customer segments. 80% of the customers are still new to our digital channels, which gives us new opportunities. And these customers are also customers who travel. They have bank account. They are bank customers. Because to do an online transaction, you need a credit card or debit card or a bank account. And there are different customer segments than our existing customers, so we don't see that big change there.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Very good. And then relative to the guidance you provided, low single-digit constant currency revenue growth for 2019. If you just think of beyond the macro piece, which is clearly out of your control, what are the factors that kind of could trade to the high or low end of that guidance range? What are the company-specific drivers that you see?

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Yes. I mean, we gave an outlook just for everyone's benefit of low single-digit constant currency growth, and that excludes the impact of anything related to -- from an Argentina inflation standpoint. Obviously, we continue to believe that our retail business will be a flattish-type growth, maybe low single digits over time, not necessarily just this year. Digital continues to have a really strong growth track record, and it's more than $500 million now. We do need to get better performance from our payments businesses, Jim. WUBS, the B2B business improved in the fourth quarter, so that's positive. It's a good step in the right direction. However, our bill payment businesses have been a little bit mixed, right. So with the devaluation of the Argentine peso, that impacts the dollar results in Argentina. Our Speedpay business was negative in the fourth quarter. So some of those things need to be better for us to be at the higher end of our outlook. We think digital is going to keep driving the key part of our consumer business. That's really where our big focus is, and it's becoming a bigger and bigger piece of that now.

HIKMET ERSEK: Yes. And part of that is also you have to think about the domestic -- yes, domestic money transfer business. Yes, domestic money transfer business is about 80% of our revenue. It's a declining business, but it impacts on the U.S. We don't have domestic money transfer business globally. Main business is our cross-border, cross-currency businesses. And U.S. domestic business has been under price pressure from Zelle and Venmo, and -- but still, they are customers. They still want to get cash, so it's about 80% of our business and had an impact also on our growth rates. But generally, I feel very confident if it comes to the cross-border, cross-currency, I don't see also any price pressure there. It's very stable. So short term, I believe that there's no price pressure there also.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. If you think broadly about the competitive environment, and not necessarily in pricing, but more just in terms of market share kind of shifts, maybe talk about how the competitive landscape has changed, if at all, over the last 2 to 3 years. I mean, clearly, there was a lot of excitement about the digital-only players. A few years ago, some of them I don't think have kind of gotten the scale they had potentially hoped. And then you have the more traditional players like MoneyGram and Euronet. So maybe just kind of help us understand how that universe is -- keep evolving from a broad level and what are the -- kind of the private players are getting stronger or weaker?

HIKMET ERSEK: Well, first of all, since 2012, or '10, '12, the business model has changed. The regulatory environment changed totally. And all your customers has to be done by the money transfer companies, not only by agents. With that, we invested a huge in our compliance programs and technology and artificial intelligence. So now your customers operating 20,000 corridors is done by our compliance machine, I would say, or cross-border platform. And doing that has changed the business model and gave us in the beginning some costs, but now it's a competitive advantage. We're operating in 200 countries, 20,000 corridors and not many companies can do that. They really hit the wall sometimes to enter a country or keep the business there. That's changed totally, but we're seeing resilience. We have seen this single-digit growth over the few years came from keeping the business there and really, again, in market share from -- based on our strength, based on our compliance environment, based on our platform. The second thing was that the traditional competitors definitely have to invest also like MoneyGram or Euronet or others have to invest also in the compliance environment and on the platform, the technology, but we started early. And we see the benefits now of that -- our compliance costs have been stable to last few years, and we are starting to put artificial intelligence technology high. We know your customer. We know the behavior of the customers. The fraud controls are getting much better. And you really comply with the global regulations in 200 countries and territories. That's a big competitive advantage we're investing in, in that case. In the digital environment -- I'm sorry, on the traditional part, basically, the competitors are going to continue to be corridor specialists. A Moroccan bank operating from France to Morocco, Mexican bank operating U.S. to Mexico. All these things will continue. That was always the case, right. That has not changed. On the digital environment, there has been in the past year, entrants in the market with the lower price environment, but it's also -- they've been only operating in certain corridors, and they could only drop money in certain way on their nonaccount. Our biggest advantage is that on the receive side, we pay out in cash or a nonaccount or on a wallet in minutes. So I can use my phone and really send money from my phone to different corridors to 200 countries immediately in 20,000 corridors and in a very efficient way. So the growth has been built on our existing capabilities. It's not that we created a new company, westernunion.com. We only sat on our existing capabilities and went globally. Now we are in 60 countries with our digital westernunion.com. And I always say to Raj, I want to be in 200 countries soon, to connect in 200 countries also with digital, not only with retail, also with digital. The other thing is also our platform now has been that effective to the compliance and settlement and technology investment, but white labeling started. The people are interested now in our platform can really collect exotic currencies like we announced during the -- Amazon announced actually. We are on the platform of Amazon for supporting their products, paid by quote, collecting funds, exotic currencies, for the goods they -- for the customers they buy. So our platform has been early -- we invest in early years. The board has supported that. We invested, as you know, in 2012, didn't do -- environment didn't do very well, but we feel much more confident to take the company to the next step.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. I guess I did want to ask about your network of agents for a second. I think you have a network of, I believe, it's over 550,000 agents at this point. How many of these agents have kind of exclusive arrangements? And has the numbers of those agents with exclusives kind of changed over time? And I guess kind of where do you see those broad kind of agent commission as a percent of revenue kind of going directionally? And how do you think about the overall agent strategy at this point?

HIKMET ERSEK: So there are 2 answers on that. First of all, the exclusives there has been there most importantly that we did not lose exclusivity on the send agents, which are most important one because once the money is in the system, it's safe in the system, right. It doesn't -- so the main agent, we never lost an agent in the last 20 years, I believe.

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Yes. But what we say, our top 40 agents have been with us for an average of 20 years. So...

HIKMET ERSEK: And they deliver the main of our revenues, right. Main of our revenues comes from the top 40 agents. And so that's very important. I think the agent relationship has been for many, many years, and that has not changed. And I don't see that, that's going to change. Our contract has been multiyear contracts. And there has been not any big -- actually, we are gaining agents. We just signed Albertsons and which is a huge network, combining with our -- that was only in the U.S. And so it is important to know that agent relationship is good. The agent commissions will go down over the years, I believe. There are 2 reasons for that. First of all, the mix. We are starting payout to our agents who have accounts, account payout, right. It's a lower cost. So there is no (inaudible) there. It's pay a lower cost. The second thing is also -- as the business model, as I mentioned earlier, has changed, there's less responsibility to know your customer on all these sites, where we take the compliance costs. I think the costs are coming down over the year, which has been the fact over the years, the costs really coming down. So but 60% of our costs are variable costs and main part of that are agent commissions. I mean, I'm ready to pay the agents more if the revenue comes higher. That will help us. But generally, the agents' commissions are coming down.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. But it's really -- you're saying driven by those 2 factors. It's the mix in terms of the account base, and it's also the fact that you're taking more of the compliance and putting it on yourself.

HIKMET ERSEK: Yes, I mean, our compliance cost has been stable, about $200 million, most of them are fixed. but still, the agents are in the payout side doing less, and then that's the formula.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes, yes. I do want to talk about the -- go back to the digital business which you kind of started to touch on. I think it's still -- last quarter, it was 21.2% revenue growth. I think it's 12% now of your overall C2C business. You talked about new markets and getting into more new markets from, I believe, 60 you said right now and then extending beyond that. What are the new markets that you kind of have seen the most incremental traction on in terms of corridors over the last year as you built enough new ones? And then where are the ones over the next year or 2 you are most excited about opening?

HIKMET ERSEK: Well, the good news is that there are still room in the existing markets and the growth is coming from the existing markets, especially from North America and European Union. That's very strong. And the interesting thing on the online business is that once you download your app or you register, you use more often our services. The retail customers are using less and their online customers are using much more our services and more often. So that's big news. The existing business has still -- the U.S. and European Union has still room to grow, and I think that's going to continue to happen on the digital business that drives the growth. The new countries are new. They grow very fast, extremely fast, but they don't have the absolute numbers yet to count on that. The new countries are -- I'm very excited about Gulf states. They just launched in the Gulf states, as you know, the Gulf states are a huge remittance market, especially to South Asia, but also to Asia and Africa. And we've just launched there the new -- our new apps from the Gulf states. That's a growth area. And that's going to continue to add on our growth. Now we are in 60 countries, and we hopefully to be in soon in 200 countries. And like we did in retail business, we started the retail business, I remember, I think, 19 years with the [company] in U.S., Canada and U.K., then Continental Europe, then Middle East, then Africa, all these things, and we are doing the same with our online westernunion.com business.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Today, in the 60-plus markets that we're in, we cover about 75% of the outbound principal opportunity.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: 75% penetration on principals?

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: No, 75% of the opportunity for outbound money transfer from digital is covered by the 60-plus markets that we're in. So there's a long tail, right. But we want to be everywhere in the world. Because long term, that is going to become a bigger opportunity for us, so -- but we have quite strong coverage, 60-plus market plus a lot of other territories that where customers can access these 60 country sites.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Got it. But the Gulf states sounds like the biggest near term kind of...

HIKMET ERSEK: Well, actually, Europe is still huge. Russia is huge. There is still room, and now we just started in Europe expansion, actually 2 years ago. I mean, we've been in U.K. and Germany, France, maybe more than a few years, but expansion in Europe just started. These are really going to add -- and then Middle East is just new but has a huge future.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: I think you talked about leveraging your kind of global network to launch the new initiatives you referred to before the whole Amazon partnership. And I think it's shop global and paying local is what you call it. What was the background behind that partnership? How did it get kind of off the ground? And how has it performed so far?

HIKMET ERSEK: Well, we just started the partnership, we are testing. Our scheme is that, as I had mentioned earlier, we invested heavily in our platform. And our platform was serving only a certain customer level, was best seen in branded products serving C2C customers, and we did that. And then we realized over the years that our platform can also be used by different people, different customers. The first were the banks. They started this, especially to serve their customers in exotic currencies. As you know, we settled -- we pay out in 137 currencies, right. And not many banks do have that access. But if you want to walk to a bank and you want to send money to Vietnam or to Egypt, you suddenly got stuck, right. And the costs were higher and everything and they say, "Okay, can I use my brand and use platform to drop money in Egypt or to drop money in Vietnam." Right. if that started -- the idea started, we said okay, Scotiabank, I mentioned it several times, was one of the first one and then Swiss Post was one of the -- also first one. It started with that idea we said, our platform can serve more than [what we're seeing] in branded customer without cannibalizing our business, and that turned out to be the right thing to do. And so what we are doing now is that offering our platform to customers, to clients like Amazon. Amazon, it's their product. It's their price. It's there to be only like a processor. And we are collecting. The people are buying online. They get a quote, and they go with that quote within 48 hours to a location. We collect the money in local currency and then Amazon gets settled and sends the goods to the customer. And that's the way how Amazon, I believe, wants to expand that. We have just started few weeks ago in 10 countries, and then we tested it. So tests are doing pretty well. We had also our learnings, right. I mean, some locations we only paid out in cash but then had to collect funds. That funds, as I see it, have to change. We have to train them, and we had to be in last mile. Look, people are connected worldwide now. They got connected. They can shop, if they're online, with smartphone from a small island in the Philippines, but they don't have the international currency to buy things. They don't have the international cards. They only have local cards or local cash. But they are connected. They want to buy our global good, and that connection is we're seeing the strength that came to that agreement.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: That's very interesting. And then, I guess, maybe kind of going back to the digital piece as well. I mean, any look at the Apple App Store or iTunes Store, you can see that you've got a really good rating in terms of the usability of the platform. And it certainly ranked among top of the market, can you maybe talk about these advantages you see from either technology perspective or scale perspective or compliance perspective relative to some of these digital competitors that you see. Is it just a matter of reach? Is it also technology? How do you think about the dimensions of that? And are any of these ad-based guys kind of a significant worry for you in terms of competitive edge, because it seems like you're way bigger than all of them and still growing very quickly.

HIKMET ERSEK: Look, if you talk about FinTech, it's called FinTech, 50-50, Fin, 50-50 -- 50%, tech; 50%, Fin. Some people forget it's all -- they believe it's 100% tech. It's not. You have to connect the needs of the customer with the technology. That's what we have done, and that's probably the most important thing. I encourage everyone here to download the Western Unionapp or -- also the audience, I'd really encourage that and test it, so you don't even (inaudible) transaction. If I go on my Western Unionapp, I can choose immediately 200 countries to send money from my bank. It's not a big tech surprise. You have to be in 200 countries to send. You have to have the licenses in 200 countries. Then you send money. You have to collect money from your bank. So if you have a collection system, how do you collect the money? You can collect money from your account. You can collect money from your debit card. You can collect from your credit card, plus we have staged transaction also. If you can't stage your transaction, go to a location-paying cash on your mobile. So combining that fund collection and fund-out model on a device technically, it's something special that Western Unioncan do it in 200 countries globally. That brought us to high ratings. It's not only the usage and obviously, we had to be all of those, that we listen to the customers, how to develop the apps and how to really be in a better situation. But the secret sauce of combining FinTech is probably what we're seeing has been doing that [167] years very well, and that's why we are leading in the digital area. I mean, we have now more than $0.5 billion revenue. As you said, it's 12% of our revenue, but it's growing very fast, 20% and contributing to our growth.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. And then you've mentioned many times before about how a lot of those digital customers are actually net new to your platform. How do you think about where all those customers are coming from? Are they coming from just simply like a web search? Are they coming from just kind of the inbound from an app store? Are they coming -- some of them kind of coming off from the traditional cash business? How do you think about analyzing that?

HIKMET ERSEK: Some of them are coming from cash business. About 80% are new, very clear. And it's always surprising year-over-year has been 80% new to us. What we do is probably we are the best ethnic marketing company of the world. We do ethnic marketing different to a Filipino in Italy than a Filipino in the U.S. We do ethnic marketing differently to Ukrainian in Germany than a Ukrainian in the U.K. Mexican, it's different. And that's exact -- and the digital environment helps us actually doing ethnic marketing in a much better way. We communicate to them in the host country in their languages. We promote in their digital environment in their languages our promotions. If you Google that, you will go -- in Turkish, in Germany, you'll get it immediately the Western Unionapp. So that -- the marketing environment is huge. And in fact, the most of our marketing dollars has now shift to digital growth. And Raj can talk about the profitability of our -- the digital business, but the growth comes from investing really in the marketing and technology environment on that environment. These customers are second, third generation of -- most of them are migrants. They'll have their global -- they are global citizens. They'll have their relatives back home. They'll want to support them, and -- but some of them, I'm sure that some of you are global citizen here. And they want to support their loved one, and they don't have time to go to a location. And while they do it right there, analytics reports here, they can also [oversee the] transactions. That's the environment we are covering today.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. So I want to put you in this for a second, Raj. I mean, I kind of want to switch to the financials a little bit and maybe kind of -- you mentioned investment areas. I want to ask about kind of R&D investment priorities and kind of product development. How do you think about like your overall budget and spend envelope for all of the activities? And kind of what are the top 2 or 3 priorities you have right now?

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Yes. The top priority is very clear. It's a lot about digital, so investing in digital growth and expansion. And it's not just we [got comm], it's all the other channels and things that go with it. So more account funding capabilities, more account payout capabilities, more mobile. We have 35 of the 60 countries that are mobile enabled today. We want to be mobile everywhere in the world just like we want to have dot-com everywhere in the world. We want it to be mobile enabled. As we see that, about 75% of transactions initiated on wu.com are done on a mobile device, even though it's not in every single country yet. So all of that takes time and money and resources and people, and so that's our #1 priority is to grow our digital business all around the world as fast as we can. And we've said that we want to be in 200 countries and territories with all these different channels and capabilities in the next few years. We haven't given a specific time line, but the next few years. Secondly, I would say it's other offshoots of what we can do digitally. So other kinds of cross-border payment opportunities, like the Amazon relationship that Hikmet talked about earlier. We can leverage our cross-border platform for other kinds of use cases that we don't have that visible today. I mean, it took us several decades to create what we created with the technology, the compliance, the ability to settle everywhere in the world in minutes, and that's something that we can leverage for other's use. We also are investing in privacy and information security and other basic things that are required. So those are, I would say, the top priorities that we have. And obviously, in a low-growth environment that we're in and with the negative currency impact, it makes it a little bit harder to get margin expansion, right, with all of the things that we want to invest in, but then we also have this low-growth environment that we're in. So we have to just balance those things as we move along.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. So in that sense, I want to ask about, which is margins. And so clearly, you've now completed the WU Way program. So I believe, $70 million of incremental savings dropping through. Can we just talk about the different levers you have? Is there anything more to pull on from a cost rationalization perspective without damaging the investment priorities that you have? And maybe talk about what the level of revenue growth is that you need, to actually drive some more margin expansion in the business?

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Sure. We're always looking for cost-efficiency opportunities. And again in a low-growth environment, it's more challenging to get the margin expansion. But with respect to our WU Way programs, we achieved $70 million run rate in savings last year, and we've basically completed the formalized part of our program where we took some charges a couple of years ago, and that's really the run rate. So we're not going to necessarily call out additional savings as we move forward, but we're absolutely focused on finding more operating efficiencies. If you look at our biggest cost item, it's commission costs in the business, right. And so we'll keep looking for opportunities there. We've done a good job, as you mentioned earlier, of bringing those costs down. Compliance costs have been relatively stable. And we're going to keep rolling out Lean in our organization. Throughout the organization, we are training everyone in our organization on Lean principles and Lean management, and -- but that's going to really go to funding things that we want to invest in. And so that's really how we think about overall margins. If we can get mid-single-digit type of revenue growth, that's really where we need to be to get the leverage on our cost structure. Real, real growth, right, not constant currency dollars, but real reported...

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Real dollars.

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Real dollars. Yes. Some of it you can actually...

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: (inaudible) domicile.

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Yes, exactly. So if we can get mid-single-digit type of growth that gives us a lot more flexibility in what we do for the bottom line.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. I wanted to ask about M&A and also kind of just the way the portfolio management of the business, make sure we ask that because we've been getting a lot of questions from investors about that topic. So if you think about the acquisition side of the balance sheet for a second, can we talk about the leverage level you feel comfortable at? And the kind of transactions you might consider in terms of acquisitions, whether they be incremental technology tuck-ins or anything incremental from like a kind of services or diversification perspective, what are the things that you kind of think about in terms of opportunities for Western Unionto just kind of diversify the business beyond what you have been today?

HIKMET ERSEK: I can go first, if you like.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Sure.

HIKMET ERSEK: Look, we're always looking for acquisitional opportunities. Obviously, we have a strong balance sheet that allows us to look around. But it should have to be aligned with our strategy. And some of the multiples, [I've said], we need is not there yet to find that golden acquisitional opportunity. If somebody knows the idea, I'm more than happy to listen, but we have the balance sheet and we are looking for that any time. Look, we are also looking at our existing portfolio, and we are looking where we are very much focused on the cross-border, cross-currency, C2B-, B2C-, C2C-related transactions, and that's what we are doing day by day and operating pretty well. Out of the core business, we may look at some opportunities to drive the shareholder value. Could be different in the different parts of the portfolio businesses, right, but our focus is going to continue to be on the C2B and B2C and C2C, and that's where we are focused on.

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: If you look at the platform we created over the last several decades, it's actually very hard for someone to replicate that, including ourselves. When we think about acquisition, it has to really advance the ball for us, right. So could we have more mobile capabilities in a year instead of 3, 4 years that it might take us? Or could we have account payout globally in 200 markets instead of over the next few years? Can we do it overnight? So those are the kinds of things we could consider, but nothing has really presented itself that would really be so much more than what we have. We can keep going at it organically, which is to build out and just leverage the platform. But if there's something else that can complement that, we'd certainly consider it, but obviously nothing's presented itself with that large, at least.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. I mean, just in terms of the existing portfolio, you've kind of like you've talked about the B2B business, whether that could be if you consider strategic alternative there, what's the calculus that you're using to evaluate that? Is it simply kind of price and return for you get? Is there -- what level of strategic alignment between what that business does today and maybe the rest of your business? And is that less or more than it was 3 or 4 years ago?

HIKMET ERSEK: I think we're very much focused on executing the business. Last quarter has been coming better than the previous quarters. I think the team is doing a good job, but we'll do everything to drive the shareholder value and the right price. We will look at that, and that's our focus. Raj and I are focused constantly on that. And the calculation is based really on the shareholder value and every calculation we will take. But the team is doing a good job the last quarter. The volatility helped a little bit, but also our payments part helped a lot. The university payments, the verticals to drive the growth. And we've seen a strong growth on the B2B business there. But again, we will do -- we are looking at everything to drive the shareholder value.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Yes. And then finally, maybe just kind of like leave it on the buyback side. And clearly, that's been a scenario we've executed pretty much nonstop over the past several years, I think like a little over $400 million return on the buyback side this past year. Failing all that in terms of acquisitions or divestitures, is there anything kind of more that you would want or could do on the buyback side beyond what you've already done?

HIKMET ERSEK: We've been giving back almost 100% of our free cash flow through both dividends and buybacks. Dividends are well over $300 million a year. Buybacks, as you said, have been in the $400 million to $500 million range. So really just comes down to how we allocate our capital. We want to keep investing in the business for all the growth opportunities that we talked about, given it's obviously a very high priority and a big use of our cash flow. We'd like to do the right kind of acquisition, but nothing major is presenting itself at least at this stage, and then we've been giving back everything else through buybacks.

HIKMET ERSEK: Plus increase of 5% on dividends...

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Yes, we just increased our dividend by 5%, so it's a key important use of our cash. And so we'll just -- we always look at those -- or in that order of priorities in how we spend our cash. You could certainly -- if you had the right kind of acquisition opportunity you could certainly flex your debt structure a bit, right, in the short term. You always get some room from the rating agency standpoint to do that. And so those kinds of things we would certainly want to evaluate.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: I think, unfortunately, we're out of time, but thank you, Raj. Thank you for being here. We appreciate it.

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Thank you very much.

HIKMET ERSEK: Thank you very much.

RAJESH K. AGRAWAL: Thanks, Jim.

JAMES EDWARD SCHNEIDER: Thanks so much. Thank you again.

urn:contentItem:60C9-G6K1-JBSJ-V1HJ-00000-00Western Union reportedly makes acquisition bid for MoneyGram2020-06-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexisWestern Union reportedly makes acquisition bid for MoneyGramRuby hinchliffe

Two of America's largest money transfer and remittance services could be joining forces.

Western Union is understood to be eyeing up rival MoneyGram as a potential acquisition candidate, Bloomberg reports. The deal would see two of America's largest money transfer and remittance services join forces.

Colorado-based Western Union has reportedly made a takeover offer for MoneyGram, but no decision has been made, and the acquirer could opt to proceed without a deal. Neither party has commented on the deal.

At the end of the first quarter of 2020, MoneyGram's total revenues were down roughly 7-8%

Dallas-based MoneyGram has suffered due to the global coronavirus lockdowns. Over the years, the firm has allocated a large portion of its technology efforts to digital kiosks, rather than website or mobile app development.

In the first quarter of this year, just 18% of MoneyGram's money was transacted digitally. The firm still relies heavily on physical channels - many of which are currently shut due to various countries' continued lockdown measures.

Traditional remittance firms face an increasingly competitive landscape. With business models built heavily around fees, both Western Union and MoneyGram have had to pivot to compete with fintechs like TransferWise which offer digital-only money transfer services at a discounted rate.

Policy makers and governments around the globe have also long been keen to cut the fees firms can charge for sending money, putting further pressure on these long-standing business models to change and adapt. According to the World Bank, it costs on average $6.79 for every $100 sent overseas.

At the end of the first quarter of 2020, MoneyGram's total revenues were down roughly 7-8%. But hours after reports on the takeover bid emerged on Monday, MoneyGram shares rose as high as 74% in late trading.

Read more: Western Union signs up Integral for BankFX system

Western Union is not the first to eye up MoneyGram

On closing, MoneyGram's market value finished on about $176.5 million, with about $878 million still in debt. Western Union's stocks rose 3.5%, finishing on a much larger market value of $8.5 billion.

Despite the public perception that MoneyGram is Western Union's slightly smaller sibling, the two firms are on opposite ends of the valuation spectrum, with TransferWise, Remitly, and WorldRemit all topping MoneyGram's valuation.

In a surprise decision last year, the money transfer service decided to sell 10% of its equity to blockchain solution provider Ripple in a $50 million deal. MoneyGram's transfer flows make XRP - the Ripple coin - more valuable, hence the investment.

But after experiencing some market volatility due to its affiliations with Ripple, MoneyGram's valuation eventually settled to back down to pre-Ripple levels.

Western Union is not the first to eye up MoneyGram. Chinese Big Tech Ant Financial agreed to acquire the remittance firm back in 2017, but the deal was abandoned when US national security regulators pushed back on the deal.

In 2007, Euronet had offered to buy the remittance firm, but MoneyGram kept stalling on the deal until its stock started to free fall and Euronet terminated its offer. It threw its hat into the ring again in 2017, and even hired lobbyists to prevent a Chinese business like Ant Financial from buying it instead.

urn:contentItem:5TMK-F7K1-DYTG-N2N6-00000-00WEST NEEDS 'TRANSATLANTIC TECH ALLIANCE' TO RADICALLY REFORM ONLINE WORLD, SAYS2018-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexisHOME NEWSWEST NEEDS 'TRANSATLANTIC TECH ALLIANCE' TO RADICALLY REFORM ONLINE WORLD, SAYS

BLAIR

By David Wilcock, Press Association Political Correspondent

Western nations should create a ``transatlantic alliance for technology'' to regulate and encourage online innovation to combat the growing influence in the sector of countries like China and India, Tony Blair has said.

The European Union and United States should create parallel regulators and give them a ``remit of rewriting the rules for the internet age'', the former Prime Minister said in the forward to a new report.

Introducing A New Deal for Big Tech: Next-Generation Regulation Fit for the Internet Age, written for the Tony Blair Institute, he said that the increasing importance of technology and its role in shaping society meant that ``now, more than ever, the private incentives of firms need to align with the public interest''.

Mr Blair suggested the new bodies start by focusing on big companies and place on them ``new responsibility on these firms, with standards built in unison with the communities they serve''.

He wrote: ``It would focus on the rights and well-being of consumers, with more powers handed to the individual to understand how their data is being used and by whom.

``It would also renew competition policy to be relevant for the economies of today.

``Practically, this means a stronger process to stop large companies buying out potentially competitive start-ups.

``With international tax reform unlikely to be forthcoming in the near future, it would also be given powers to place companies temporarily in a corporate-tax regime which allocates profits geographically in proportion to active users.

``Together the reforms would place the US and the EU at the forefront of setting ethical standards for tech worldwide. But importantly, they would encourage, not stifle innovation.''

The intervention comes after Chancellor Philip Hammond announced on Monday that online tech giants such as Amazon and Google will be slapped with a new digital services tax as part of a package of measures meant to ease the burden on the beleaguered high street.

As part of the Autumn Budget, he said a 2% UK digital services tax would come into force in April 2020 and is expected to raise £400 million a year.

It will only be paid by profitable companies that generate at least £500 million a year in global revenues.

It applies to income firms generate through providing search engines, social media platforms and online marketplaces.

As well as powers governing tax and the buying out of smaller competitors, the report also suggests allowing the regulators to:

- Set and enforce standards on tech firms, with the power to impose sanctions for ``reckless or negligent behaviour''.

- Ensure firms create tools that allow consumers to ``search, control and export data'' shared with online services, with extra transparency and information over third party usage.

- Create ``safe harbours'' to test ways of overcoming ``economic and social challenges'', and be able to recommend the removal or reform of ``obsolete rules that inhibit innovation or the public interest''.

Mr Blair wrote that ``This competitive edge will be key'', adding: ``Many parts of the developing world have begun to converge economically with Europe, while China is vying with the US.

``This should not be a zero-sum game; it is simply the new reality.''

Report author Chris Yiu said that anti-globalisation sentiment was being compounded by ``a backward-looking turn against technology''.

He added: ``There is no question that the tech sector has brought much of the current firestorm on itself, but politicians and policymakers are complicit too.

``Today, the internet is not just another sector: it has escaped into and disrupted all of them.

``To find a sustainable solution, policymakers need to understand how the world has changed. Instead of quick-fixes or knee-jerk reactions, we need regulation fit for the internet age.''

urn:contentItem:5XJJ-GHK1-DY19-C2CX-00000-00Westpac gets tangled up in globalised underbelly2019-11-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexisWestpac gets tangled up in globalised underbellyThe AFR View

Systems will fail but systemic flaws will be fixed by true corporate leaders. That's the lesson, again, of the latest bank scandal.

Fast and cheap international money transfers symbolise the global mobility and tech-connectedness possible in the gig economy. These payment systems allow foreign workers to easily remit wages home and let aged pensioners retire securely anywhere in the world. But these systems also expose the underbelly of globalisation when targeted by international criminals. This is why Westpac will pay a huge financial penalty for its systemic breaches of the laws that help the authorities stop the wash of dirty money around the globe.

Westpac has admitted to breaching reporting and record-keeping requirements in relation to 23 million transactions between 2013 and 2018. These include failing to report 19.5 million international transfers worth $11 billion due to a programming glitch in the automated reporting systems. It also failed to do due diligence on 16 overseas banks it has international transfer arrangements with. By choosing the faster and cheaper LitePay remittance system - to work around the SWIFT global payment system judged too slow and expensive to handle low value, large volume transfers - Westpac is accused of allowing banks in high-risk jurisdictions to access Australia's banking system and facilitating money laundering. As detailed in regulator AUSTRAC's statement of claim, Westpac cannot trace where funds originated in significant numbers of transfers.

AUSTRAC says that Westpac's failures mean that it has been prevented from doing its job and detecting suspicious and criminal activity. The most distressing aspect of the AUSTRAC case is that more than 3000 transfers on Westpac's payment systems may have been used to fund child pornography. In 2013 Westpac was made aware by both the regulator and its own risk assessments about links between alleged child exploitation and frequent low value transfers to the Philippines and south-east Asia. Then in June 2016, senior management was specifically briefed by AUSTRAC on how such payment patterns were consistent with "child exploitation typologies". But it was only in June 2018 that an effective detection control scenario - which is still deemed incomplete by the regulator - was established to identify suspicious patterns of low value regular payments over the LitePay system.

This new banking scandal - which comes soon after CBA's record $700 million fine for its anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism breaches - will add to the regulatory pressures that are distracting Australia's reputation-battered banks from focusing on core commercial functions. Without making excuses, the distractions including falling margins in a low interest rate world, mixed messages from the government about driving investment and from ASIC about responsible lending, and the myriad social issues from climate change to diversity that bankers are meant to solve. Maybe the judgment will be that some countries are too risky to stay in the international transfer business. Modern banks are supposed to be customer-focused and establish flexible systems that make transactions as seamless as possible including across national borders. But it has long been the reality that international transfers can raise red flags for criminal activity, and banks have an integral role to play alongside regulators and the police in law enforcement.

AUSTRAC blames "indifference" by Westpac's senior management and inadequate oversight by the board for the bank's financial crime controls being five years out of date and unsatisfactory. CEO Brian Hartzer rejects the claim the bank didn't care. He also says he first heard about child exploitation on Wednesday morning, and that he won't resign. Westpac partially self-reported its breaches, has admitted guilt, and will seek to settle rather than fight the AUSTRAC case. But why, despite the warnings in 2013 and 2016, did nothing happen until 2018 to flag payments suspected of paying for child porn? The timeline appears to damn Westpac's leadership.

No system is ever foolproof, especially when complex big-tech platforms digitise more and more of the economy. But failing to tackle systemic failings is another matter. If the chain of command works, flawed systems can be fixed before a crisis occurs, if they get the right attention from senior management and boards. Relevant therefore remains Graeme Samuel's excoriating review of CBA's culture of widespread complacency, overconfidence, excessive complexity and insularity.

The true test of the culture of an institution is not only whether red flags are waved but are acted upon. This is the message that should once again reverberate round the nation's C-suites and boardrooms as Westpac awaits the size of the fine that it will pay for its inaction on dirty money.

urn:contentItem:5TJ3-VK81-JBJ7-N1HC-00000-00Westpac warns players 'out of step' on tech2018-10-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexisWestpac warns players 'out of step' on techPaul Smith

Westpac's tech boss has warned of long-term problems for Australia's economy if banks, government, regulators and tech giants fail to improve the way they work together.

Westpac Banking Group's technology boss Dave Curran has warned of long-term problems for the Australian economy if banks, government, regulators and technology companies do not improve the way they work together to address new challenges posed by digital advances.

In a colourful address to a Trans-Tasman Business Circle event on Friday afternoon, the influential tech executive laid bare the challenges facing institutions caused by impending open banking rules and yawning technology skills shortages, and warned the country risks being left behind in the tech-driven world without better co-ordination.

Mr Curran is due to retire from the bank at the end of the year, after piloting an   ambitious overhaul of systems that leaves it at the forefront of technology in the   cloud computing era.

However he said he was worried about how Australia would fare in the years to come, and feared banks would struggle to match regulators' wishes without greater co-ordination.

Despite the increasing prominence of tech companies, he warned Australia was falling behind in developing world-class capability across all sectors.

He said banks were a good starting point for leading change because they were Australia's biggest and most influential tech-enabled businesses.

"In my near five years at Westpac we've spent over $10 billion on technology. We are part of a large ecosystem consisting of many players including policy makers, regulators, educators, big tech companies and start-ups - and that's before we even talk about our staff and our customers," he said.

"The problem is that the players in this ecosystem are often out of step with each other. We are like a bunch of diverse people at a dance, but each dancer has a different tune in their head and moves to their own rhythm.

"We spend a lot of time looking at our feet, rather than at the dynamics of the dance floor. As a result, heads bump and toes get stepped on."

Open banking

One of the most pressing issues for the big banks in the immediate future is the introduction of so-called open banking, which is the first stage of opening up access to citizens of the data held on them by organisations across sectors.

By July 1 next year banks will be required to make data available on all credit and debit cards, deposit and transaction accounts, which will also include application programming interfaces for fintech start-ups to create new products.

Mr Curran said Westpac was supportive of open banking and wanted to make it work, but warned there was still a significant amount of work that needed to be done, which was hampered by regulatory uncertainty and a lack of understanding among the broader population of the privacy impacts.

He said technical, regulatory and service standards were not yet clear and balanced and said if regulators didn't co-ordinate fully or consult with affected parties it would lead to significant duplication, poor integration and greater complexity across organisations.

Data privacy

"I have over 600 people working in my cyber security team, because protecting the data is a massive part of what we need to do, but in open banking we will be making some of that data available to a small company that actually just wants data because data is their business ... even though that is not what they tell customers," Mr Curran said.

"If we don't get privacy and cyber things right as we go into open banking, it's very hard to fix it once it's broken. We're rushing pretty fast, [but] we need a clearer conversation with the community about what this means."

He said Millennials in particular were often relaxed about the idea of sharing their data until they personally experienced the reality of being hacked and having their digital identity stolen.

He said Westpac saw a few hundred cases of identity theft each month, and it took a significant toll on the victims. Maintaining security standards in the open era remains a big challenge.

"Being hacked and losing 50 bucks is one thing, but when you lose your digital identity that's completely different," Mr Curran said.

"If someone says you've got to change your email address tomorrow, the effort to do that is massive, but if you've actually lost your entire digital identity it is one of those things that until you experience it, it's not [considered] a big problem.

"The obligation of people like me and the roles of the banks and other areas, that still hold a significant degree of trust in the community, is to actually protect that."

Mr Curran has previously spoken out about the shortage of Australians with relevant technology skills, with the onus on both business and the education system to change to match the changing workforce requirements.

He cited recent Deloitte estimates that demand for tech workers would grow by almost 100,000 by 2023, as a big opportunity for the local workforce, which was currently being missed.

"There are fewer than 5000 domestic graduates from tech degrees each year, so the only way we'll reach workforce targets is by either importing labour or sending work offshore, much as we've done for the past five years. We now have a broken supply-and-demand equation," Mr Curran said.

"Our best and brightest kids are still signing up to become doctors and accountants and lawyers, when we know that there will be a decreasing need for all these professions because of the digital revolution ... We need more of our young people - and especially young women - coming into the workforce with skills in artificial intelligence, data science, cyber and even blockchain."

Big tech problems

In his speech Mr Curran also took aim at the lack of consideration given by major global tech suppliers to Australian customer needs. Westpac spent over $1 billion with big tech firms like IBM, Amazon Web Services, Microsoft and Oracle, but said they didn't always receive the focus needed.

"Big tech companies sometimes complain that we call them suppliers rather than partners, but we do this because it's true. We are treated as customers not true partners and long-time collaborators," he said.

"I can turn up after a weekend and discover that 30 staff, who were working with my team on Friday aren't there on a Monday, because of a decision we didn't know about made in some offshore intergalactic HQ.

"I'd like to see Big Tech genuinely transform and become less of a performer and more of the partner they claim they want to be; responding to our aspirations, becoming more flexible, and aligning more closely to our strategic goals."

urn:contentItem:5TJ4-1F51-JD34-V2MS-00000-00Westpac warns players 'out of step' on tech2018-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:56ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL SERVICESPg. 17Westpac warns players 'out of step' on techPaul Smith

Westpac Banking Group's chief information officer Dave Curran has warned of long-term problems for the Australian economy if banks, government, regulators and technology companies do not improve the way they work together to address new challenges posed by digital advances.

In a colourful address to a Trans-Tasman Business Circle event on Friday afternoon, the influential tech executive laid bare the challenges facing institutions caused by impending open banking rules and yawning technology skills shortages, and warned the country risks being left behind in the tech-driven world without better co-ordination.

Mr Curran is due to retire from the bank at the end of the year, after piloting an ambitious overhaul of systems that leaves it at the forefront of technology in the cloud computing era.

However, he said he was worried about how Australia would fare in the years to come, and feared banks would struggle to match regulators' wishes without greater co-ordination.

"In my near five years at Westpac we've spent over $10 billion on technology. We are part of a large ecosystem consisting of many players including policy makers, regulators, educators, big tech companies and start-ups - and that's before we even talk about our staff and our customers," he said.

"The problem is that the players in this ecosystem are often out of step with each other. We are like a bunch of diverse people at a dance, but each dancer has a different tune in their head and moves to their own rhythm.

"We spend a lot of time looking at our feet, rather than at the dynamics of the dance floor. As a result, heads bump and toes get stepped on."

One of the most pressing issues for the big banks in the immediate future is the introduction of so-called open banking, which is the first stage of opening up access to citizens of the data held on them by organisations.

By July 1 next year banks will be required to make data available on all credit and debit cards, deposit and transaction accounts, which will also include application programming interfaces for fintech start-ups to create new products.

Mr Curran said Westpac was supportive of open banking and wanted to make it work, but warned there was a significant amount of work that needed to be done, which was hampered by regulatory uncertainty and a lack of understanding among the broader population of the privacy impacts.

He said technical, regulatory and service standards were not yet clear and balanced and said if regulators didn't co-ordinate fully or consult with affected parties it would lead to duplication, poor integration and greater complexity across organisations.

"I have over 600 people working in my cyber security team, because protecting the data is a massive part of what we need to do, but in open banking we will be making some of that data available to a small company that just wants data because data is their business ... even though that is not what they tell customers," Mr Curran said.

Mr Curran has previously spoken out about the shortage of Australians with relevant technology skills, with the onus on both business and the education system to change to match the changing workforce requirements.

He cited recent Deloitte estimates that demand for tech workers would grow by almost 100,000 by 2023, as a big opportunity for the local workforce, which was currently being missed.

"There are fewer than 5000 domestic graduates from tech degrees each year, so the only way we'll reach workforce targets is by importing labour or sending work offshore, much as we've done for the past five years. We now have a broken supply-and-demand equation," Mr Curran said.
